Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Non-Isotropic Networked Sensor Deployment for Smart Buildings

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this proposal is to thoroughly investigate the deployment of non-isotropic sensors for smart building applications. Various sensing and control applications in smart building require accurate and efficient localization and tracking of human and activities. To achieve this goal, the non-isotropic networked sensor deployment is essential.

This proposal addresses a new set of problems arising from the deployment of four types of sensors: cameras, tripwire, motion sensors and microphones. The set of deployment problems would strive for full sensor coverage and wireless connectivity with a complex floor plan, and involve one or more of the following constraints: (i)Non-isotropic model using visibility (cameras and tripwires), (ii) Non-overlapping sensing range, (iii) Robust 2-coverage for accurate localization. The sensor deployment problem will heavily involve the geometric properties of the environment (building layout), as well as the geometric properties of the sensors (non-isotropic sensing ranges). Ideas from computational geometry will be applied to tackle these problems and approximation algorithms with worst-case guarantee for theoretical rigor as well as practical algorithms suitable for implementations will be developed.

A clear understanding on how to deploy sensors for smart building systems will allows for efficient planning and effective practice of networked sensor deployment to achieve the high quality sensing desired by various indoor applications. For developers, this work will significantly reduce the design and development costs for designing and building smart building systems. For end users, the resultant testbed will lead to exciting applications that will significantly improve the quality of life. It also enriches engineering curriculum to integrate the theory of computational geometry with the system building practice. The PIs are committed in improving female presence in computer science and exposure of research for high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Smart building applications face a number of challenges that arise from the environment structures, sensor properties and application requirements. The geometric complexity of floor plans as well as obstacles in the environment creates non-trivial geometric or topological features in the domain of study. Therefore, sensor deployment, scheduling and operations in the smart building domain require solving complex optimization problems.

Coverage

Being a fundamental problem, sensor deployment has been studied for a number of years. The difference in our work is that we consider sensors with line of sight coverage ranges, thus having the flavor of classical art gallery problem. Second, we consider multi-coverage requirement using infrared for indoor localization, we need each target to be covered by at least two sensors. We provide matching combinatorial upper/lower bounds on the number of sensors needed as well as algorithms for near optimal coverage plan [1]. In a camera network, we consider the connected camera network problem when all cameras must form a connected graph using wireless radios. We proved the hardness of this problem and provided a 2-approximation [2]. 

Scheduling

Once the sensors are deployed to ensure full coverage of the domain, we schedule the operation of the sensors to minimize the energy consumption. The problem is motivated by two observations. First, the sensor deployment problem considers the worst scenario and needs to make sure all locations are covered. But the same location could be monitored/covered by multiple sensors thus having inherent redundancy. Second, in many monitoring/tracking applications interesting activities have certain durations and can be captured fine as long as the target is monitored sufficiently often. We can selectively turn on a subset of the sensors in a carefully designed order such that application quality does not suffer. With this motivation we developed algorithms for joint sensor duty cycle coverage problem, which minimizes the number of sensors turned on while satisfying the given heterogeneous requirements, or maximize the coverage requirement when the number of sensors turned on is fixed. For both versions we provide efficient approximation algorithms that can be implemented in practice [4]. In a related problem, we use a mobile node (MULE) to collect data from sensors where the sensors can have different storage size/data generation rate. Again we have non-trivial problem to design the best schedule for the MULE to maximize data collected. We provide constant approximation algorithms for a single MULE, k-MULEs and multiple MULEs [5]. We study the problem of finding the charging path maximizing the number of nodes charged within a fixed time horizon. We prove that this problem is APX-hard. We design a quasi-polynomial time algorithm that achieves polylogarithmic approximation to the optimum charging path [10]. In [11], we formally define the time-constrained data harvesting problem, which seeks an optimal data harvesting path in a network to collect as much data as possible within a time duration, then we devise PTAS algorithms.

Routing

We considered three problems. The first one is called beacon based routing in which beacons are deployed and we investigate what type of guarantee one can obtain by greedy routing towards the beacons. We provide combinatorial bounds on the number of beacons needed and considered beacon based aggregation (when there is a common destination) and beacon based dissemination (when there is a single source) [6]. The second problem we considered homotopic routing --- finding a path of a given homotopy type, i.e., getting around the holes in a specific order. We provide the first distributed algorithm that achieves a constant stretch using greedy routing decisions [7]. Last we improved our understanding of load balanced routing. We use area-preserving map to show that greedy routing can achieve a constant approximation factor in any simply connected domain [8] and show a rigorous proof that routing using medial axis in fact achieves a constant approximation with a small tweak [9]. 

1. Kin Liu, etc, Joint Sensing Duty Cycle Scheduling for Heterogeneous Coverage Guarantee, INFOCOM'17.

2. Hua Huang, etc, Connected Wireless Camera Network Deployment with Visibility Coverage, INFOCOM’14.

3. Esther Ezra, etc, Distributed Algorithm for Approximate Mobile Sensor Coverage, CCCG’14.

4. Kin Liu, etc, Joint Sensor Duty Cycle Scheduling with Coverage Guarantee, MobiHoc’16.

5. Gui Citovsky, etc, Exact and Approximation Algo- rithms for Data Mule Scheduling in a Sensor Network, ALGOSENSORS 2015 and TCS.

6. Michael Biro, etc, Combinatorics of Beacon Routing and Coverage, CCCG’13.

7. Kan Huang, etc, Bounded Stretch Geo-graphic Homotopic Routing in Sensor Networks, INFOCOM’14.

8. Mayank Goswami, etc, Load Balanced Short Path Routing in Large-Scale Wireless Networks Using Area-Preserving Maps, Mobihoc’14.

9. Jie Gao, etc, Medial Axis Based Routing Has Constant Load Balancing Factor, ESA 2015.

10. L. Chen, etc, Charge Me If You Can: Charging Path Optimization and Scheduling in Mobile Networks. MobiHoc'16.

11. C. Lin, etc, Time-constrained Data Harvesting in WSNs: Theoretical Foundation and Algorithm Design. INFOCOM'15.
